articles.headline: E.U. Debates Which Nation Will Regulate Web Privacy
articles.snippet: As the European Union nears agreement on a law for information privacy, some expect one nation’s regulators to enforce the rules throughout the union.
articles.abstract: As the European Union nears agreement on a law for information privacy, some expect one nation’s regulators to enforce the rules throughout the union.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The new European Parliament that was voted into office over the weekend, despite having a different political makeup, is widely expected to reach a final agreement this year on stricter online privacy rules that have long been in the works.

articles.headline: Applying the Lessons of Politics to Green Power
articles.snippet: Ethical Electric, a start-up founded by a former Washington political operative, allows customers to sign up for electricity from renewable sources.
articles.abstract: Ethical Electric, a start-up founded by a former Washington political operative, allows customers to sign up for electricity from renewable sources.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the years, Tom Matzzie — by working as a political operative on John Kerry’s 2004 presidential campaign and on building the antiwar movement that helped usher President Obama into office — became convinced that the key to creating change was to make it easy for people to participate.

articles.headline: U.S. Training Elite Antiterror Troops in Four African Nations
articles.snippet: United States Special Operations troops are forming elite units in Libya, Niger, Mauritania and Mali in the war against Al Qaeda’s affiliates in Africa.
articles.abstract: United States Special Operations troops are forming elite units in Libya, Niger, Mauritania and Mali in the war against Al Qaeda’s affiliates in Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — United States Special Operations troops are forming elite counterterrorism units in four countries in North and West Africa that American officials say are pivotal in the widening war against Al Qaeda’s affiliates and associates on the continent, even as they acknowledge the difficulties of working with weak allies.

articles.headline: 13 Deaths, Untold Heartache, From G.M. Defect
articles.snippet: Guilt, doubt and blame have plagued the people touched by a General Motors ignition switch defect that has killed 13 people.
articles.abstract: Guilt, doubt and blame have plagued the people touched by a General Motors ignition switch defect that has killed 13 people.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEN WHEELER, Tex. — For most of the last decade, Candice Anderson has carried unspeakable guilt over the death of her boyfriend. He was killed in 2004 in a car accident here, and she was at the wheel. At one point, Ms. Anderson, who had a trace of Xanax in her blood, even faced a manslaughter charge. She was 21.
articles.byline: By Rebecca R. Ruiz, Danielle Ivory and Hilary Stout

articles.headline: N.Y.U. Crisis in Abu Dhabi Stretches to Wall Street
articles.snippet: The general contractor that helped oversee the construction of the Abu Dhabi campus is run by a trustee of N.Y.U.’s board.
articles.abstract: The general contractor that helped oversee the construction of the Abu Dhabi campus is run by a trustee of N.Y.U.’s board.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Lipton, the superlawyer, has advised hundreds of boards of directors in the midst of crises. Now, however, Mr. Lipton is grappling with a board governance crisis of his own.

articles.headline: Unlikely Allies Uniting to Fight School Changes
articles.snippet: Teachers, lawmakers and parents from the left and right are banding together to fight against new high-stakes standardized tests and other hot-button policies in public education.
articles.abstract: Teachers, lawmakers and parents from the left and right are banding together to fight against new high-stakes standardized tests and other hot-button policies in public education.
articles.lead_paragraph: SMYRNA, Tenn. — She is a fan of MSNBC, supports abortion rights and increased government spending in schools, and believes unions should have the right to strike. He watches Fox News, opposes abortion and is a fiscal conservative who voted three years ago to strip teachers unions of collective bargaining rights.

articles.headline: A Bet on Florida Pays Off
articles.snippet: The state’s economy is on the rise because of low prices for land and contractors, and tourism driven in part by a new Harry Potter attraction.
articles.abstract: The state’s economy is on the rise because of low prices for land and contractors, and tourism driven in part by a new Harry Potter attraction.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — In 2008, when American businesses were almost universally hoarding cash in a struggle to survive the financial crisis, Harris Rosen made a different call.

articles.headline: Campus Killings Set Off Anguished Conversation About the Treatment of Women
articles.snippet: Friday’s fatal rampage in Southern California has given rise to anguished talk about the ways women are perceived sexually and the violence against them.
articles.abstract: Friday’s fatal rampage in Southern California has given rise to anguished talk about the ways women are perceived sexually and the violence against them.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLA VISTA, Calif. — A deadly attack by a gunman obsessed by grievances toward women near the campus of the University of California, Santa Barbara, has touched off an anguished conversation here and on social media about the ways women are perceived sexually and the violence against them.

articles.headline: U.S. Troops to Leave Afghanistan by End of 2016
articles.snippet: The withdrawal of combat troops from Afghanistan will allow the United States to confront an emerging terrorist threat from the Middle East and Africa, President Obama said.
articles.abstract: The withdrawal of combat troops from Afghanistan will allow the United States to confront an emerging terrorist threat from the Middle East and Africa, President Obama said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, declaring that it was “time to turn the page on a decade in which so much of our foreign policy was focused on the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq,” announced on Tuesday that he planned to withdraw the last American troops from Afghanistan by the end of 2016.

articles.headline: Once Allies, Ex-Obama Aides Face Off in British Campaign
articles.snippet: Jim Messina, who managed President Obama’s re-election campaign, has crossed an ideological divide to do the same for Prime Minister David Cameron.
articles.abstract: Jim Messina, who managed President Obama’s re-election campaign, has crossed an ideological divide to do the same for Prime Minister David Cameron.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — David Axelrod stood on a stage in the Buckingham Room of the Labour Party headquarters this month, rallying British progressives who are hoping, and paying, for Barack Obama’s message maven to help lead them back into power.
